summary: This week we're sharing a series called TED Connects, Community and Hope. This one features philanthropist Bill Gates in a virtual conversation with head of TED Chris Anderson and Whitney Pennington Rogers

This week we're bringing you interviews from some of the world's greatest minds to offer tools for us to navigate through and thrive in these really uncertain times. We're going to switch gears a little bit today from thinking about our own personal mental health to the state of our global public health
Bill Gates: "This is an unprecedented really disconcerting time for everyone" "I'm lucky that I get to connect up with video conferencing using Teams a lot"

Five years ago, you stood on the TED stage and you gave this this chilling warning that the world was in danger at some point of a major pandemic. What happened? Did people listen to that warning at all?

Last month, you said that this might be the big one. You wrote that this could be the sort of once in a century pandemic that people had been fearing. Sadly, very little was done. There were some things. The Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovation,
"This is a, you know, it's going global. How many people end up dying? Hopefully, if we do the right things, it won't be a gigantic number" "We should end up not having a 1918 flu situation"

With most respiratory viruses like the flu and COVID, at first, you only feel a little bit of a fever. And so there's the possibility you're going about your normal activities and infecting other people. So Ebola, you're actually flat on your back before you're very
"It's January where everybody should have been on notice. Let's get our act together with testing. There are putics and vaccines. We've got to get organized," he says
"This is a really big deal. What are we doing? What, what was happening behind the scenes during that period? Well, you'd like to have government money show up for the key activities," he says

"I'm just so confused as to why with more than a month's notice. I mean, there are so many smart epidemiologists in the, in the US," he says. "The sooner you do it in a, in a top way, they sooner you can undo

The government hasn't stepped in to make sure that the testing capacity is both increased and it's used for the right cases. There'll be a website and if the federal government doesn't do it a lot of local governments, I'll have to do it, that you go to

"Testing is the key thing, South Korea did that in this massive way that everybody should learn from," he says. "Our goal here is to get to the point where a very small percentage of the populations infected"
Tech companies are very involved in making sure that some work can go on. They can help with the visibility of the numbers. Back in 1918, they didn't have this type of visibility

Bill Bennett: One of the riddles about this isolation strategy is how long it has to last. Bennett: A lot of people are concerned that the price of victory by isolating everyone is that you crash the economy. He asks: What is the isolation strategy that eventually leads to us

"It's very hard to tell people when there's an epidemic spreading that, you know, threatens particularly their parents or elderly people that they should go about things knowing that their activity is spreading this disease" "I don't know of any rich countries that have chose to use that approach

A few countries in Europe that hadn't really looked at this hard, considered, okay, should be, we'd be the ones who kind of go about business as usual. South Korea did not have to do the extreme shutdown because they did such a good job on testing

It is sad that the shutdown will be harder for poor countries than it is for richer countries. Japan has not contained it quite in the same way as South Korea did. The US has passed this opportunity to control without shutdown

The experience that we're seeing in China and in South Korea is that there are not these people who are asymptomatic that are causing lots of infections. There's a lot we don't know. For example, seasonality may help us in the northern hemisphere. The force of

How is it possible that the combination of the shutdown in Wuhan and measures elsewhere seem to have got to the point where there are literally no new cases happening? I mean, to me that implies that literally the virus is not circulating at all between humans in China
Local infection rates, below one, sorry. That's that quarantine, that's, you know, quarantine comes from 40 days, which is what they thought would help for black, black plague

If you were president for a month in the US, what would be the top two or three things you would do? Well, the clear message that we have no choice to maintain this isolation. That is our primary technique. Thank God we have testing
"We need a clear message about that," he says. "It is really tragic that the economic effects of this are very dramatic" "This is not going to be easy," he adds

If rich countries do their job well, by the summer, they'll be like China is, are some of the other countries that responded early. But in the developing countries, particularly in the southern hemisphere, the seasonality is large. We do need to get really cheap testing out to

The Gates Foundation and Welcome Trust, with support from MasterCard and others, created this therapeutics accelerator to really triage out. The only good news is that the rich countries have this. And so they will be learning about testing therapeutics and funding the vaccines

One possibility might be treatments from the serum, the blood serum, of people who had had the disease and recovered. People who are recovered, it appears, have really effective antibodies in their blood. So you could go, transfuse them and only take out the white cells

Is it possible that in a few months' time that there's going to be this growing need to test for these antibodies and people to see if someone had the disease and recovered, maybe they didn't even know they had it?

With expensation, you know, you could get past that three million. I believe we will be able to avoid that with the having this economic pain. Eventually, what we'll have to have is certificates of who's a recovered person
"It's so terrifying to see signs of countries starting to blame each other or, you know, that the xenophobia just seems so toxic," he says

I see that countries that are recovered can help other countries. There are vaccine projects all over the world. Unfortunately, whenever you have disease, this sense of other and foreign and no stay away from me, that sort of pulling inward is reinforced
Seasonality may help. IE, high temperatures. Is it possible that that is so far protecting place to some extent, places like India
The wild card is how well can the developing countries deal with this? I'm very worried that there will be a massive number of deaths in those poor countries. And that is going to be very difficult

The Gates Foundation, we vary only on gay about 100 million to help out with all the pieces, the testing piece, the therapeutics and the vaccines. We are not experts in making masks and ventilators and gowns, and it's great that other people, including some 3

Five years ago I said that the pandemic is this unaddressed, very, very scary thing. And that, you know, if we did the right things, we could be more prepared. Sciences on our side, the fact we can be ready for the next epidemic, it

I'm still very much an optimist, you know, whether it's climate change, countries working together, biology taking the diseases. And yes, it will take tens of billions, but not hundreds or trillions of dollars. It'll be tiny compared to the economic cost

Bella: I'm very positive that this should draw us together. We will get out of this and then we will get ready for the next epidemic. We can't say for sure that even the rich countries will be out ofThis in six to ten weeks

The world as a whole with its great science and desire to help each other was able to try and minimize what happened there and avoid it happening again. That's certainly the optimistic scenario that I'm craving for myself

There's an amazing analog right with climate. It's just a different time scale that the scientists are out there saying, there's this huge enemy coming. And so, I don't think this has to be a huge setback for climate

There are thousands of people watching, many of them living alone, some scare, there may be these people there who have this virus and suffering symptoms or recovering. By the way, if that's you, we'd love to hear from you

Whitney: "It's to be smart about this, you know, it's like get ahead of it. If you're in a part of the world where this thing hasn't really hit, listen to Bill Gates" "These days are what the internet was built for. We
